title: Girl, 16, found hanged hours after telling mum she was 'betrayed' by Childline
text:

A schoolgirl was found hanged after telling her mum she had been “betrayed by Childline” which gave her confidential details to police, an inquest heard.

Jesse Walker, 16, contacted the counselling charity via a live chat service while alone in her room to talk about the suicidal thoughts she was having.

The Childline operator knew only that the teen was called Jesse and the family home was in the seaside town of Scarborough, North Yorkshire.

But after Jesse cut short the conversation Childline was so concerned for her welfare that they contacted the National Crime Agency, asking them to trace the IP address of her computer.

When Pc James Dunn, of North Yorkshire Police, showed up at her home at 1.30am he was told by Jesse’s stunned mum that the girl was asleep in bed.

(Image: Ben Lack Photography Ltd)

Having checked that the girl was in no immediate danger, the officer left.

He told the inquest: “Mrs Walker was aware Jesse had been on the internet earlier in the evening.

“But she seemed okay after that. My Concerns for her immediate safety were met.”

Childline sent him a transcript of the conversation with Jesse which he also forwarded to a mental health worker whom Jesse had been seeing.

When the teenager found out Childline had shared her details with police, she was devastated, the inquest heard.

Her mum Heather told the hearing: “Jess was so angry that her confidence had been breached and the police had been around.

“She said she felt betrayed by Childline. She said she was tired and went back to sleep. She did not go to college that morning."

Jesse stayed home and watched TV but seemed fine. In the evening, she was pottering around her room while Heather went out with a friend.

When Heather returned later in the evening, Jesse’s stepdad, Simon, said the teenager was still up in the room.

Heather went up to give her some chocolates to cheer her up – and found the schoolgirl hanging.

Simon cut the teen down and her distraught mum tried desperately to save the girl with heart massage and the kiss of life, the inquest heard.

Paramedics also made desperate attempts to revive her but she never regained consciousness and died later the same evening on January 23 this year.

The inquest heard Jesse had passed all her GCSEs but had a history of self-harming and became stressed while study for A Levels at Scarborough Sixth Form College.

Heather told the hearing that no one had told her daughter was suicide risk and the "beautiful soul" had been a casualty of a “catalogue of errors” by those supposed to be supporting her.

Coroner Jonathan Heath recorded a narrative verdict that Jesse had been found dead by her mum after leaving suicide notes.

But he did not make any recommendations after hearing that the mental health organisations involved had learned lessons from the tragedy.

They had met Childline, who had only spoken to the police about their concerns for Jesse, and it had been agreed that the agencies needed to work closer together in the future.

Childline, originally inspired by an idea by That’s Life presenter Esther Rantzen, has been run by the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children since 2005.

An NSPCC spokesman said: “This is terribly sad and our thoughts are with Jesse’s family. However, we cannot comment on individual cases.”

The Samaritans is available 24/7 if you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling 116 123, email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter.
description: Jesse Walker, 16, from Scarborough, North Yorkshire, contacted Childline through a live chat and told an operator she had been having suicidal thoughts
